The current study delves into the mechanistic intricacies of azide-alkyne cycloaddition reactions (MAAC) catalyzed by transition metals (M = Cu, Ag, and Au) bound to N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands, utilizing Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations at the MN12-L/Def2-SVP level of theory, with Def2-TZVP for metal atoms, to shed light on the 1,4-regioisomer formation. A detailed comparison between mono- and bi-nuclear catalytic pathways for these metal complexes is presented. Our findings underscore the nuanced role of the metal identity in dictating the reaction's course, with a notable preference for a stepwise mechanism across the board, except in the mononuclear pathway of Au and Ag, which follows a concerted mechanism. The activation energies, analyzed in toluene solvent, underscore the efficiency of the binuclear pathway for all metals, showcasing significantly lower activation barriers (18.76 kcal/mol for Au and Ag, and 8.47 kcal/mol for Cu) compared to the mononuclear route. This distinction highlights the potential for optimizing catalytic performance through careful selection of metal-NHC combinations, providing valuable insights for the design of efficient catalysts in click chemistry applications. The study not only reaffirms the superior efficacy of the binuclear pathway but also enriches our understanding of metal-catalyzed MAAC reactions, contributing to the advancement of catalysis science and offering avenues for the development of novel synthetic strategies in organic chemistry. Introduction The azide-alkyne Huisgen cycloaddition is a fundamental organic reaction mechanism involving a 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition between an azide molecule and a terminal or internal alkyne, yielding a 1,2,3-triazole compound Scheme 1 . This reaction, elucidated by Rolf Huisgen [1-4], represents a pivotal milestone in organic chemistry. Renowned American chemist Karl Barry Sharpless has lauded this cycloaddition as exemplifying the pinnacle of click chemistry. Click chemistry [5-9] has revolutionized the field of synthetic chemistry by providing efficient and reliable strategies for the synthesis of complex molecular architectures. Among the diverse click reactions, copper(I)-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) has garnered significant attention owing to its exceptional selectivity and versatility [10-25]. CuAAC enables the formation of 1,2,3-triazoles by coupling an azide and an alkyne and has widespread applications in medicinal chemistry, materials science, and bioconjugation [26-32]. In recent years, alternative catalytic systems have been explored to expand the scope and efficiency of click chemistry. Notably, gold (I)- and silver(I)-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloadditions (AuAAC [33-39] and AgAAC [40-49], respectively) have emerged as promising alternatives to CuAAC. These catalysts offer unique advantages such as enhanced reactivity, compatibility with diverse functional groups, and the ability to operate under mild reaction conditions. Transition-metal catalysts play a pivotal role in facilitating click reactions, and the incorporation of N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) (Fig. 1 ) as ligands has gained considerable attention [50-58]. NHCs possess desirable properties, including high nucleophilicity, tunable steric and electronic attributes, and exceptional stability, making them effective ligands for transition-metal complexes. Combining NHCs with transition metals in AgAAC, CuAAC, and AuAAC reactions provides opportunities to optimize reaction rates, selectivity, and functional group compatibility. 1,4-Disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles derived from click reactions exhibit intriguing structural features and versatile applications. These compounds are of particular interest because of their potential as pharmacophores with diverse biological activities. The ability to selectively modify both the 1,4- and 1,5-positions of the triazole scaffold allows the synthesis of structurally complex molecules and libraries with tailored properties [8-13,34,35,42-44]. Computational methods have become indispensable tools for understanding the mechanisms and properties of chemical reactions. In this study, we computationally investigated the reactivity and selectivity of transition metal catalysts, namely copper, silver, and gold, in conjunction with NHCs in AgAAC, CuAAC, and AuAAC reactions. This study employs density functional theory (DFT) calculations to explore the energetics, reaction pathways, and stereochemistry associated with these catalytic systems. Furthermore, we will utilize the powerful computational tool Multiwfn [59] to perform noncovalent interaction (NCI) [60-63] analysis on the synthesized 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles. The NCI analysis enables the identification and characterization of attractive and repulsive interactions within triazole compounds, providing valuable insights into their stability, binding properties, and potential applications. By combining experimental and computational approaches, this study aims to deepen our understanding of the reactivity and selectivity of transition-metal catalysts, along with NHC co-catalysts, in AgAAC, CuAAC, and AuAAC reactions. The insights gained from this computational investigation will contribute to the rational design of efficient catalyst systems for click chemistry, thereby facilitating the synthesis of functionalized 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles with tailored properties. These advances hold great potential for applications in drug discovery, materials science, and chemical biology. This article presents a computational study on the utilization of transition-metal catalysts (Cu, Ag, and Au) with NHCs in AgAAC, CuAAC, and AuAAC reactions Fig. 1. This study aimed to elucidate the reactivity, selectivity, and mechanistic aspects of these catalytic systems, along with the synthesis and properties of 1,4-Disubstituted. Computational methods In this study, computational calculations were performed to investigate the properties and behavior of transition metals using the MN12-L [64] functional with the Def2-TZVP basis set for transition metals and the Def2-SVP basis set for other elements [65]. The G16 package was utilized for these calculations [66], with additional single-point calculations conducted using the conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM) at the same level of theory [67]. Vibrational frequencies were computed to ensure the presence of one imaginary frequency in transition states. The electronic energies (Eo ), Hcorr, Gcorr , and optimized geometries of the catalytic cycle components in the gas phase were obtained (supplementary information). Our literature review of computational chemistry revealed a challenge faced by computational chemists in obtaining the structure of reactive complexes (RC) in cycloaddition reactions [49], despite experimental evidence supporting their existence. It prompted us to explore different DFT methods, ultimately identifying our optimal approach (MN12-L/Def2-SVP, with the Def2-TZVP for transition metals) for its accuracy and efficiency. This approach met convergence criteria and successfully obtained RC structures [10,22,23,40], The results obtained using our methodology were satisfactory and consistent with experimental observations. Non-Covalent Interaction (NCI) [60-63] analysis is used in such studies to provide a detailed understanding of the weak interactions that play a critical role in molecular recognition and stability. These interactions, which include hydrogen bonds, van der Waals forces, and π-π stacking, can significantly influence the structure, reactivity, and properties of transition metal complexes and catalytic cycles. By employing NCI analysis, researchers can visualize and quantify these interactions, gaining insights into the underlying mechanisms that govern the behavior of the system under study. This information is crucial for designing more efficient catalysts and understanding reaction pathways in greater depth. Results and discussions McNulty's group introduced the first example of Ag(I)-catalyzed AAC reactions, referred to as AgAAC, offering an alternative to CuAAC reactions for the selective synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted-1,2,3-triazoles at ambient conditions [44]. Subsequently, their group developed new Ag(I) complexes with reduced toxicity by employing Ag(I) in conjunction with P, O-containing ligands [45]. In contrast to the extensively studied mechanisms of copper-catalyzed AAC reactions [10-25], the mechanism and regiochemical outcomes of the AgAAC process remain ambiguous and necessitate thorough and systematic investigation. Tuzun et al. [49]. conducted the first theoretical exploration of the AgAAC mechanism, drawing on McNulty's group's work [44]. Utilizing Ag-PPh3 as the catalyst via their theoretical level (wB97XD/6–31+G(d) for main elements, MWB28 effective core potential for Ag, Gaussian 09), for binuclear pathway they were unable to corroborate the established CuAAC mechanism, proposing instead a novel mechanism through the analysis of an Ag(I)-acetylide structure. They considered binuclear Ag-acetylide structures containing two alkynes with one PPh3 ligand as initial Ag-acetylide structures. Still, they couldn't obtain the reactive complex RC structures despite using diverse DFT methods and basis sets. In 2023 [40], we re-evaluated this study using Ag-PPh3 along with two additional catalysts from McNulty's group [45], confirming the mechanism aligned with the CuAAC pathway and successfully identifying the RC structures through DFT methods (MN12-L or MN15-L) with Def2-SVP for main group elements and Def2-TZVP for transition metals. For CuAAC, the general mechanism is well-established and documented in most literature. We conducted a study with diimine and phosphorus ligands [10]. Regarding gold, studies on the mechanism of AuAAC remain limited. We study the use of transition-metal catalysts (Cu, Ag, and Au) coordinated with N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands in AgAAC, CuAAC, and AuAAC reactions. Mononuclear and binuclear mechanisms have been proposed to explain this process. Mononuclear mechanism In the context of mono- and bi-nuclear MAAC (metal- azide-alkyne cycloaddition) reactions, the involvement of M-acetylides (Ac-Ln) as a starting point in the catalytic cycle has been proposed and supported by a range of experimental and computational investigations [3-27,40,45,48,49] as depicted in Scheme 2 . To provide further insights, we present the MN12-L optimized structures of M-acetylides with NHC ligands (Ac-m) in Fig. 2 to illustrate the reactive complex (RC-m) and transition state (TS1-m) structures involved in the mononuclear (m) pathway. The catalytic cycle starts from the metal-acetylide, which coordinates with the azide to form the RC-m, from which the intermediate compound (a six-membered ring) IC-m is generated through a TS1-m, which is the rate-determining step because it has the highest energy barrier. The reaction pathway continues to form the metal-triazolide (P-m) through a TS2-m, which usually has a lower energy barrier than TS1-m for the formation of 1,4-Disubstituted 1,2,3-Triazoles P. If copper is used, but gold and silver metal are used, IC-m and TS2-m are not obtained in the reaction pathway. Table 1 presents the calculated M– N inner (M = Cu, Ag, and Au) distances for the RC-m compounds using the MN12-L functional, which were 2.785, 3.360, and 3.490 Å, respectively. For the TS1-m structures, the M– N inner distances were 2.008, 2.373, and 2.806 Å, respectively, for the mononuclear pathways. In our previous study [10], the calculated Cu– N inner distance for TS1 with Cu-diimine was 2.003 Å, and with Cu-PPh3 1.975 Å. For Ag-PPh3 the Ag– N inner distance was 2.397 Å, and with 2-(di‑tert-butylphosphaneyl)-N,N-diisopropylbenzamide, it was 2.438 Å [40]. Conversely, the Ag– N inner distance with Ag-PPh3 was 2.380 Å in the study by Tuzun et al. [49]. The computational results in Fig. 3 show the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG 298 ) values of the catalytic cycle components with toluene as a solvent along the reaction pathway. The ΔG 298 of the reactive compounds RC-m were positive, indicating non-spontaneity with 2.3, 3, and 5 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively. For Cu-diimine and Cu-PPh3, the ΔG 298 were 3.8 and −3.8 kcal/mol, respectively [10]. For Ag- PPh3 and 2-(di‑tert-butylphosphaneyl)-N,N-diisopropylbenzamide were −3.1 and 5.7 kcal/mol, respectively [40]. As previously mentioned, TS1 is the rate-determining step of the reaction due to its highest activation Gibbs free energy (AGFE) barrier. The AGFEs of the TS1-m were 15.4, 25.7, and 28.2 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively. For Cu-diimine and Cu-PPh3, the AGFEs were 15.1 and 10.1 kcal/mol, respectively [10], while for Ag- PPh3 and 2-(di‑tert-butylphosphaneyl)-N,N-diisopropylbenzamide, they were 31.2 and 23.6 kcal/mol, respectively [40]. In the study by Tuzun et al., the AGFE for Ag- PPh3 was found to be 32.9 kcal/mol [49]. The free energy barrier ( E # ) of a chemical reaction is defined as the difference in Gibbs free energy between the (TS) and the nearest ground state (RC). This can be expressed mathematically as: E # = D G t r a n s i t i o n s t a t e TS − D G r e a c t i v e c o m p l e x RC The E # values for TS1-m are 13.2, 22.7, and 23.2 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively Scheme 3 . The E # with the AGFE, consistently indicates that Cu is more favorable than Ag, which in turn is more favorable than Au. Some researchers prefer to discuss the effectiveness and efficiency of catalysts based on the energy barriers E # . However, we prefer to discuss them based on AGFE because, from our perspective, it is important not to neglect the energies associated with the formation of the RC. Accordingly, the activity of transition metals towards the MAAC reaction related to the mononuclear pathway can be arranged as follows: Cu>Ag>Au. Binuclear mechanism Similar to the mononuclear pathway, the binuclear (b) reactions in this study follow a stepwise mechanism as depicted in Scheme 2. The initial step involves the interaction between the M-acetylide (Ac-b) and azide molecule. The structures of the MN12-L reactive complex (RC-b) and the transition states (TS1-b) associated with the binuclear pathway are shown in Fig. 4 . In comparing the M– N inner distances in the RC-b compounds, calculated using the MN12-L method and presented in Table 2 , notable variations are observed. The distances for Cu, Ag, and Au were found to be 2.104, 2.902, and 3.469 Å, respectively, with corresponding M– N outer distances of 3.058, 3.391, and 3.525 Å. For the transition state TS1-b, the M– N inner were 1.954, 2.218, and 2.246 Å for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively. The Cu– N inner for TS1-b with Cu-diimine and Cu-PPh3 were 2.018 and 1.989 Å respectively [10]. For Ag-PPh3 of the Ag– N inner and 2-(di‑tert-butylphosphaneyl)-N,N-diisopropylbenzamide were 2.610 and 2.369 Å with [40]. In contrast, Tuzun et al. reported an Ag– N inner of 2.260 Å for Ag-PPh3 [49]. The M–M distances for TS1-b were 2.425, 2.793, and 2.832 Å for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively, highlighting significant differences in the metal-metal interactions among these catalysts. These variations in distances provide insights into the different catalytic behaviors and stabilities of the transition states across different metal centers, emphasizing the unique properties of each catalyst in the AAC reactions. The binuclear mechanism was investigated and the ΔG 298 required for the formation of the reactive compounds RC-b in toluene were determined. The calculated values, presented in Fig. 3, reveal ΔG 298 of approximately −3.7, −1.8, and −0.2 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively. For Cu-diimine and Cu-PPh3, the ΔG 298 were 0.7 and −2.1 kcal/mol, respectively [10]. For Ag- PPh3 and 2-(di‑tert-butylphosphaneyl)-N,N-diisopropylbenzamide were −10.2 and −1 kcal/mol, respectively [40]. Notably, the ΔG298 of the RC-b compounds were negative, indicating high spontaneity compared to the mononuclear pathway. The AGFEs for the TS1-b were also evaluated, resulting in values of 8.5, 18.8, and 20.7 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively Fig. 3. For Cu-diimine and Cu-PPh3, the AGFEs were 7.6 and 16.8 kcal/mol, respectively [10], while for Ag- PPh3 and 2-(di‑tert-butylphosphaneyl)-N,N-diisopropylbenzamide, they were 29.1 and 25.5 kcal/mol, respectively [40]. In the study by Tuzun et al., the AGFE for Ag- PPh3 was 25.7 kcal/mol [49]. the E # values for TS1-b are 12.2, 22.6, and 20.9 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively, Scheme 3 . Based on these findings, the activity of the transition metals in the MAAC reaction, as it relates to the mononuclear pathway, can be ranked as follows: Cu > Ag > Au. Monon- vs Bi-nuclear pathways The Gibbs free energy ΔG 298 values calculated using the MN12-L method in toluene for the mono- and bi-nuclear pathways with the NHC ligand, presented in Scheme 3 and Fig. 3, reveal significant differences in the AGFEs of TS1, the rate-determining transition state. The AGFEs of TS1 for the mononuclear pathways were consistently higher compared to the binuclear pathways across all three transition metals. Specifically, the AGFEs for Cu, Ag, and Au in the mononuclear pathway were 15.43, 25.66, and 28.20 kcal/mol, respectively, while the corresponding values in the binuclear pathway were 8.47, 18.76, and 20.71 kcal/mol. These results suggest that the binuclear pathway is energetically more favorable, likely due to the metal-metal M–M bridge playing a crucial role in the binuclear pathway by significantly reducing the energy barrier of the transition states compared to the mononuclear pathway. In the binuclear mechanism, the presence of two metal centers allows for more efficient stabilization of the transition state through cooperative interactions between the metals. This stabilization occurs because the M–M bridge facilitates electronic communication and sharing of the catalytic load, which effectively lowers the activation energy required for the reaction to proceed. In contrast, the mononuclear pathway lacks this dual-center interaction, leading to higher energy barriers as a single metal center must bear the entire catalytic load. The absence of the M–M bridge in the mononuclear pathway results in less effective stabilization of the transition state, thereby increasing the energy required to reach the transition state. Solvent effects For the mononuclear mechanism Scheme 4 , the AGFEs of TS1-m in the gas phase are 12.7, 22.8, and 25.9 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively. In toluene, these values increase to 15.4, 25.7, and 28.2 kcal/mol, respectively. This indicates that the presence of toluene as a solvent lead to higher AGFEs compared to the gas phase. For the binuclear mechanism, the AGFEs of TS1-b in the gas phase are 7.9, 17.7, and 20 kcal/mol for Cu, Ag, and Au, respectively. In toluene, these values increase to 8.5, 18.8, and 20.7 kcal/mol, respectively. Similar to the mononuclear mechanism, the AGFEs in toluene are higher than those in the gas phase. Using toluene as a solvent significantly impacts all participating intermediates, ground states, and transition states (supplementary information). Analysis of the results indicates that the AGFEs are generally higher when toluene is used as a solvent compared to reactions conducted in the gas phase. This effect can be attributed to several factors related to the nature of toluene as a solvent. Solvent-solute interactions play a major role in increasing the energy barriers, as toluene, an organic solvent with a relatively low dielectric constant, reduces its ability to stabilize charges on intermediates and transition states. This leads to an increase in the energy required to reach these states, thereby increasing the energy barriers. Additionally, interactions between toluene molecules and reaction participants contribute to this effect, as toluene can interact with solutes through dispersion interactions, which, although relatively weak, are numerous, thus increasing the energetic stability of transition states and intermediates and leading to higher energy requirements to reach these states. Specific interactions between toluene and solutes, such as hydrogen bonds or π-π interactions, can further affect energy barriers, complicating the energetic environment of the reaction and increasing energy barriers. NCI and RDG analysis NCI (Non-Covalent Interactions) analysis provides a powerful tool for investigating the intricate interactions between molecules, particularly those that do not involve the sharing of electrons in traditional covalent bonds [60,61]. By examining the electron density and its derivatives, NCI allows researchers to identify regions of significant electron localization or delocalization indicative of non-covalent interactions. These interactions encompass a wide range of phenomena, including hydrogen bonding, van der Waals forces, π-π stacking, and electrostatic interactions. In NCI analysis, particular attention is paid to the peaks observed in the reduced density gradient (RDG) at low electron densities. These peaks represent regions where the electron density is significantly different from its surroundings, highlighting areas of potential non-covalent interaction. By visualizing these regions, researchers can gain insights into the spatial distribution of electron density and the strength of various intermolecular forces. RDG analysis, on the other hand, provides a quantitative method for studying NCI by examining the electron density and its associated scalar and vector fields. RDG is rooted in Density Functional Theory (DFT), which establishes a connection between electron density and energy [62,63]. By analyzing the gradient of the electron density, RDG allows researchers to map out regions of high electron concentration (indicative of covalent bonds or lone pairs) and low electron concentration (indicative of non-bonding or electron-deficient regions). The computational tool Multiwfn 3.8 [59] was employed to perform the calculation and analysis of the NCI and RDG properties [60-63], as detailed in the supplementary information. To visualize the results with enhanced accuracy, the VMD program was used to generate charts and color maps. From the NCI and RDG plots depicted in Figs. 5 , 6 , 7 , and 8 analysis of the transition states TS1 within the mono- and bi-nuclear pathways reveals distinctive features. Notably, a prominent green disk, accompanied by brown staining, is observed between the benzyl-azide ring and the NHC ring. This observation is indicative of van der Waals interactions, underscoring the non-covalent forces at play. Conversely, a smaller red disk is discernible between the six-membered ring, where nitrogen and carbon atoms from the azide and alkyne respectively, congregate with the transitional metal. Conclusion The present study employed Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the mechanism of transition metal-catalysed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (MAAC) reactions with N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands, specifically focusing on transition metals M= Au, Ag, and Cu, in both mononuclear and binuclear pathways. Our computational results have revealed valuable insights into the intricacies of MAAC reactions. Our findings indicate that, in general, MAAC reactions predominantly proceed through a stepwise mechanism, elucidating the reactivity of these metal-NHC complexes. However, it is noteworthy that a distinctive one-step mechanism was observed in the mononuclear pathway for Au and Ag, suggesting intriguing differences in their catalytic behavior. Of particular significance is the dominance of the binuclear pathway across all the transition metals studied. This notable finding underscores the critical role played by binuclear complexes in these reactions and highlights their potential as efficient catalysts for various synthetic applications. Remarkably, the lowest energy barrier observed in our calculations was a mere 8.47 kcal/mol, attained with Cu-NHC in the binuclear pathway. Such low activation energy values are promising indicators of enhanced catalytic efficiency and reactivity for Cu-NHC complexes. The investigation into the influence of NHC ligands and the diverse nature of transition metals on MAAC reactions offers a deeper understanding of these catalytic processes. The comprehensive knowledge gained from this study could pave the way for the development of more selective and efficient catalysts for future applications in synthetic chemistry. coredata.dc:description: The current study delves into the mechanistic intricacies of azide-alkyne cycloaddition reactions (MAAC) catalyzed by transition metals (M = Cu, Ag, and Au) bound to N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands, utilizing Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations at the MN12-L/Def2-SVP level of theory, with Def2-TZVP for metal atoms, to shed light on the 1,4-regioisomer formation. A detailed comparison between mono- and bi-nuclear catalytic pathways for these metal complexes is presented. Our findings underscore the nuanced role of the metal identity in dictating the reaction's course, with a notable preference for a stepwise mechanism across the board, except in the mononuclear pathway of Au and Ag, which follows a concerted mechanism. The activation energies, analyzed in toluene solvent, underscore the efficiency of the binuclear pathway for all metals, showcasing significantly lower activation barriers (18.76 kcal/mol for Au and Ag, and 8.47 kcal/mol for Cu) compared to the mononuclear route. This distinction highlights the potential for optimizing catalytic performance through careful selection of metal-NHC combinations, providing valuable insights for the design of efficient catalysts in click chemistry applications. The study not only reaffirms the superior efficacy of the binuclear pathway but also enriches our understanding of metal-catalyzed MAAC reactions, contributing to the advancement of catalysis science and offering avenues for the development of novel synthetic strategies in organic chemistry.
